description: From French embouchure, from emboucher (“to put in one’s mouth”), from en- (“in”) + bouche (“mouth”), from Latin bucca (“cheek”).

entries.meaning: (music) The use of the lips, facial muscles, tongue, and teeth when playing a wind instrument.
examples: you could see the twin lines running down from either side of his lower lip, etched in by the force of his embouchure, looking like extensions of his mustache.

entries.meaning: (archaic) The mouth of a river or valley.
